results.ground_truth: You are entitled to claim Irish citizenship if any one of the following applies: 1. You were born in Ireland or Northern Ireland before 1 January 2005 2. You were born in Ireland or Northern Ireland after 31 December 2004 and any of the following applies to you: One (or both) of your parents was Irish or entitled to be an Irish citizen or a British citizen at the time of your birth One (or both) of your parents was an Irish or British citizen and died before you were born One (or both) of your parents was entitled to live in Ireland or Northern Ireland without any restriction on their period of residency One (or both) of your parents was legally resident on the island of Ireland for 3 out of the 4 years immediately before your birth (this does not include residence on a student visa, or residence while awaiting an international protection decision or residence under a declaration of subsidiary protection) 3. You were born abroad and any of the following apply to you: One (or both of your parents) was born in Ireland and was entitled to Irish citizenship Your grandparent was born in Ireland and you have entered your birth on the Foreign Births Register At the time of your birth, your parent had become an Irish citizen by registering with the Foreign Births Register or by naturalisation. You must register your birth with the Foreign Births Register before obtaining Irish citizenship. 4. You were born in Ireland and are not entitled to be a citizen of any other country.
results.question: Who is entitled to Irish citizenship?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: Who is entitled to Irish citizenship?

Helpful Answer:

Irish citizenship can be acquired in several ways:
1. Birth - A person born on the island of Ireland or abroad to an Irish parent(s) has a claim to Irish citizenship by birth under certain conditions. If both parents were Irish citizens, then the child receives Irish citizenship automatically at birth. However, if only one parent was an Irish citizen, then certain residency requirements must also be met, such as being resident in Ireland for three years before the child's birth.
2. Naturalization – Non- Irish individuals who have spent sufficient time residing in Ireland and meet various criteria such as having no criminal background may apply to become naturalized Irish citizens after generally spending four out of the previous five years res
results.answer:
Irish citizenship can be acquired in several ways:
- Birth - A person born on the island of Ireland or abroad to an Irish parent(s) has a claim to Irish citizenship by birth under certain conditions. If both parents were Irish citizens, then the child receives Irish citizenship automatically at birth. However, if only one parent was an Irish citizen, then certain residency requirements must also be met, such as being resident in Ireland for three years before the child's birth.

results.ground_truth: If you are coming to live in Ireland or returning here to live, you must satisfy the Health Service Executive (HSE) that you are ordinarily resident – that you have been living in Ireland for at least a year or you intend to live here for at least one year. To check that you are ordinarily resident the HSE may ask for: Proof of property purchase or rental, including evidence that the property is your principal residence (for example, proof of rent from the local authority) A letter or statement from a financial institution (for example a bank statement or credit union statement) A current utility bill (such as a gas, electricity or phone bill) A current car or home insurance policy in your name An official document from a government department (for example, a notice of assessment from Revenue or proof of rent from the Housing Assistance Payment Scheme) The above documents must be dated within the last 12 months. Any person, regardless of nationality, who is accepted by the HSE as being ordinarily resident in Ireland is entitled to either full eligibility (Category 1, medical card holders) or limited eligibility (Category 2) for health services.
results.question: What is ordinary residence?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is ordinary residence?

Helpful Answer:

Ordinary residence refers to an individual's usual place of abode or permanent home in Ireland where they have strong connections with the State that go beyond their mere presence in the country. This includes having access to public services, being employed, studying, or otherwise participating fully in social and economic life here. It is an important concept for determining eligibility for certain benefits and entitlements under Irish law. For more detailed information on this topic, please consult the Citizens Information website (https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/) or reach out directly to a member of our team through online chat, email, or phone.
results.answer: Ordinary residence refers to an individual's usual place of abode or permanent home in Ireland where they have strong connections with the State that go beyond their mere presence in the country. This includes having access to public services, being employed, studying, or otherwise participating fully in social and economic life here. It is an important concept for determining eligibility for certain benefits and entitlements under Irish law. For more detailed information on this topic, please consult the Citizens Information website (https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/) or reach out directly to a member of our team through online chat, email, or phone.

results.ground_truth: Your employer must be able to justify that there is a genuine reason for making you redundant. A genuine redundancy is one where your employer has a real business reason to make you redundant. Reasons for redundancy include: Financial difficulties within the business: for example, your employer needs to cut costs and this means staff numbers must be reduced. Lack of work: for example, your employer no longer needs or has a reduced need for employees with your skills or new technology has made your job unnecessary. Reorganisation within the business: for example, your employer has decided to carry on the business with fewer or no staff or the job you do no longer exists. Business closure: the business is closing down or moving.
results.question: What counts as genuine redundancy?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What counts as genuine redundancy?

Helpful Answer:
Genuine redundancy occurs when an employer cannot continue to employ someone in a particular job because either the job no longer exists or is required less due to a change in the business operations, such as relocating, reorganizing, or closing down completely. To qualify for certain state payments like Jobseeker’s Benefit (JB) or Social Welfare Contributions, you must be able to prove that you have been made genuine redundant by providing documentation from your former employer. Some examples may include letters confirming cessation of employment or a letter outlining why your position was eliminated, and copies of any agreements you signed related to severance packages. Additionally, if you were offered alternative work within the same
results.answer: Genuine redundancy occurs when an employer cannot continue to employ someone in a particular job because either the job no longer exists or is required less due to a change in the business operations, such as relocating, reorganizing, or closing down completely. To qualify for certain state payments like Jobseeker’s Benefit (JB) or Social Welfare Contributions, you must be able to prove that you have been made genuine redundant by providing documentation from your former employer. Some examples may include letters confirming cessation of employment or a letter outlining why your position was eliminated, and copies of any agreements you signed related to severance packages.

results.ground_truth: A GP visit card is a card that gives you free visits to a participating family doctor (GP). If you are not eligible for a medical card, you may be eligible for a GP visit card. You can apply for a GP visit card online.
results.question: What is a GP visit card?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is a GP visit card?

Helpful Answer:
A GP Visit Card provides free access to essential General Practitioner (GP) services in Ireland. This means you won't have to pay medical cards rates when visiting your family doctor. The card is available for certain categories of people such as children under six years old, those receiving specific social welfare payments or those who meet income-related criteria. It's important to note that not all GP services are covered; patients may still need to pay for any additional tests, prescriptions, or procedures outside of the GP consultation itself. For detailed information about eligibility or application conditions, please visit www.citizensinformation.ie
results.answer: A GP Visit Card provides free access to essential General Practitioner (GP) services in Ireland. This means you won't have to pay medical cards rates when visiting your family doctor. The card is available for certain categories of people such as children under six years old, those receiving specific social welfare payments or those who meet income-related criteria. It's important to note that not all GP services are covered; patients may still need to pay for any additional tests, prescriptions, or procedures outside of the GP consultation itself. For detailed information about eligibility or application conditions, please visit www.citizensinformation.

results.ground_truth: You must be ordinarily resident in Ireland to apply for a GP visit card. This means that you are living in Ireland and intend to live here for at least one year. You will qualify for a GP visit card with no means test if you are: Aged under 8 (see GP visit cards for children) Aged over 70 Getting Carer’s Benefit or Carer’s Allowance, at full or half-rate If you are aged under 70, your income is assessed by the HSE to see whether you qualify for a GP visit card. See below for information about the HSE basic rates of income.
results.question: Who can get a GP visit card?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: Who can get a GP visit card?

Helpful Answer:
The GP Visit Card is available to certain categories of people living in Ireland. These include individuals who are under 6 years old or over 70 years old, those receiving qualifying social welfare payments, some families with children, homeless persons, patients suffering from chronic illnesses, refugees, and asylum seekers. Additionally, people whose medical cards have been suspended or are awaiting review may also be eligible for the GP Visit Card. For more specific details about eligibility and how to apply, please check out the CIH website (www.citizensinformation.ie) or contact the Health Service Executive directly at 1850 24 1850.
results.answer: The GP Visit Card is available to certain categories of people living in Ireland. Additionally, people whose medical cards have been suspended or are awaiting review may also be eligible for the GP Visit Card. For more specific details about eligibility and how to apply, please check out the CIH website (www.citizensinformation.ie) or contact the Health Service Executive directly at 1850 24 1850.

results.ground_truth: Online applications are completed in approximately 20 working days for first-time applicants. If you are applying by post, you should allow at least 8 weeks for your application to be processed (not including postage times). This period may be extended at certain times of the year due to increased application numbers. First-time postal applications from the UK take at least 8 weeks. You can check the Passport Service website for current processing times.
results.question: How long will my passport application take?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: How long will my passport application take?

Helpful Answer:

The processing time for an adult Irish passport application can typically range from 3-4 weeks if applied via Passport Online or Post, or from 2 weeks up to 10 working days if you apply in person at one of the Passport Offices located in Dublin, Cork, Galway, Limerick, Letterkenny, and Tralee. However, these times can vary depending on factors such as peak periods, any errors or omissions within the application form, and if further verification is required. For urgent travel needs (within 5 working days), there may be extra fees involved for this expedited delivery process for both adults and children. Keep in mind that you should apply well before your current pass
results.answer: The processing time for an adult Irish passport application can typically range from 3-4 weeks if applied via Passport Online or Post, or from 2 weeks up to 10 working days if you apply in person at one of the Passport Offices located in Dublin, Cork, Galway, Limerick, Letterkenny, and Tralee. However, these times can vary depending on factors such as peak periods, any errors or omissions within the application form, and if further verification is required. For urgent travel needs (within 5 working days), there may be extra fees involved for this expedited delivery process for both adults and children.

results.ground_truth: A Police Certificate is an official statement about you issued by An Garda Síochána. It is used by people who have lived in Ireland and want to work or study abroad. It is required by some foreign authorities. A Police Certificate states your: Name Address Date of birth Criminal record in Ireland (this does not include adult cautions) A Police Certificate is normally valid for 1 year. You should also note that the Irish spent convictions legislation cannot be used to prevent disclosure when you are required to disclose information about your criminal convictions to another state.
results.question: What is a Police Certificate?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is a Police Certificate?

Helpful Answer:
A Police Certificate, also known as a Garda National Central Bureau (GNCB) certificate, is a document issued by An Garda Síochána in Ireland confirming that an individual has no criminal record or any unspent convictions recorded against them under Irish law. It is often required when applying for visas, work permits, immigration status, certain licenses, adoptions, or foreign employment.

Obtaining a Police Certificate involves filling out an application form, providing personal identification documentation such as passport and proof of residence, and paying the applicable fee. Applications can be lodged online at the GNCB website, by post, or in person at selected An Garda Siochana
results.answer:
A Police Certificate, also known as a Garda National Central Bureau (GNCB) certificate, is a document issued by An Garda Síochána in Ireland confirming that an individual has no criminal record or any unspent convictions recorded against them under Irish law. It is often required when applying for visas, work permits, immigration status, certain licenses, adoptions, or foreign employment.

Obtaining a Police Certificate involves filling out an application form, providing personal identification documentation such as passport and proof of residence, and paying the applicable fee.

results.ground_truth: Each local authority maintains the Register of Electors for its area. To be included in the Register of Electors, you must: Be at least 18 years old Be ordinarily resident at an address in Ireland If you are homeless or have no address, you can still register to vote by stating that you have ‘no fixed address.’ Read more about being homeless and registering to vote. If you have more than one address, you should give the address where you want to be registered. You can only be registered at one address. You can register to vote: Online at checktheregister.ie By filling in an application form If you do not give a PPS number, you must get your form and ID witnessed at a local Garda station or your local authority.
results.question: How to register to vote?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: How to register to vote?

Helpful Answer:
To register to vote in Ireland, follow these steps:
1. Check that you meet the eligibility requirements, which include being aged 18 or over on polling day, an Irish citizen, living at a specified address (or in certain circumstances, listed apart from the electoral register), and not disqualified from voting by law.
2. Fill out Form RFA3 "Registration to Vote" available from the Electoral Register Office or online through the website of the Electoral Commission (C Éireann). Be sure to enter all necessary details accurately.
3. Attach proof of identity and sign the form if it is provided separately as per the instructions given on the application form. Accepted forms
results.answer:
To register to vote in Ireland, follow these steps:
- Check that you meet the eligibility requirements, which include being aged 18 or over on polling day, an Irish citizen, living at a specified address (or in certain circumstances, listed apart from the electoral register), and not disqualified from voting by law.
- Fill out Form RFA3 "Registration to Vote" available from the Electoral Register Office or online through the website of the Electoral Commission (C Éireann). Be sure to enter all necessary details accurately.
- Attach proof of identity and sign the form if it is provided separately as per the instructions given on the application form.

results.ground_truth: The Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant provides funding so you can refurbish vacant and derelict homes. It can also be used to renovate vacant and derelict properties that have not been used as residential properties before. However, this only applies if the non-residential properties were used for commercial or public use before and now have the correct planning permission. You can get the grant if you are refurbishing the vacant property so you can live there, or so you can rent the property out. You can get a grant of up to €50,000 to renovate a vacant property and up to €70,000, if the property is derelict. You can get more if you are living on an off-shore island. And, there is an additional grant for expert conservation advice if you are refurbishing a vacant traditional farmhouse. The Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant is funded by the Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage through the Croí Cónaithe (Towns) Fund and you apply to your local authority. If you have questions about the grant or want to know if your property qualifies, you can: Read the FAQs about the grant Contact the Vacant Homes Officer in your local authority Contact the Housing Agency's Vacancy Helpline on vacancycampaign@housingagency.ie You can also find information on how to re-use old and vacant buildings in the Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage’s Bringing Back Homes (pdf) manual.
results.question: What is the Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is the Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant?

Helpful Answer:
The Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant (VPRG) is a financial assistance scheme provided by the Department of Housing, Local Government, and Heritage in Ireland. This grant aims to encourage homeowners to restore vacant properties or long-term empty houses that do not meet minimum standards of habitation as defined under the local authority and planning laws. The grant can cover up to €30,000 or 90% of eligible costs related to repairing, refurbishing, or renovating a vacant property. For more detailed information and eligibility criteria, I recommend visiting their website at www.housing.gov.ie
results.answer: The Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant (VPRG) is a financial assistance scheme provided by the Department of Housing, Local Government, and Heritage in Ireland. This grant aims to encourage homeowners to restore vacant properties or long-term empty houses that do not meet minimum standards of habitation as defined under the local authority and planning laws. The grant can cover up to €30,000 or 90% of eligible costs related to repairing, refurbishing, or renovating a vacant property. For more detailed information and eligibility criteria, I recommend visiting their website at www.housing.gov.

results.ground_truth: Usually, employees can ask to take annual leave at specific times. Your employer can accept your request, or refuse your request. Your employer decides when annual leave may be taken, but this is subject to a number of conditions. Your employer must: Take into account your family responsibilities, as well as the available opportunities for rest and recreation. Discuss your annual leave with you (or your union) at least one month before you are to take the leave.
results.question: Can my employer force me to take annual leave?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: Can my employer force me to take annual leave?

Helpful Answer:

Under Irish law, employers can ask employees to take their statutory annual leave at certain times, as long as they give reasonable notice. However, an employer cannot insist that an employee takes annual leave if it would cause serious hardship or harm to the employee or another person (for example, by denying care responsibilities). If you have any concerns about being forced to take annual leave, I recommend contacting the Workplace Relations Commission for advice.
results.answer: Under Irish law, employers can ask employees to take their statutory annual leave at certain times, as long as they give reasonable notice. However, an employer cannot insist that an employee takes annual leave if it would cause serious hardship or harm to the employee or another person (for example, by denying care responsibilities). If you have any concerns about being forced to take annual leave, I recommend contacting the Workplace Relations Commission for advice.

results.ground_truth: If you are sick while you are on annual leave, you should get a medical certificate from your GP (doctor) as soon as possible to cover the days you were sick. Give the medical certificate to your employer as soon as you return to work. This way, the sick days will not count as annual leave, and you can take your annual leave at a later date. Your employer cannot make you to take annual leave for time you were on certified sick leave.
results.question: What if I get sick while on annual leave?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What if I get sick while on annual leave?

Helpful Answer:
If you become ill during your annual leave, it is important to reach out to your employer as soon as possible to inform them of our situation. If your employment contract includes sick pay benefits or you have access to state sick pay through social welfare, they will need to know how long your illness may last. However, each case depends on individual circumstances, so it would be best to consult with your HR department for accurate advice regarding sickness policies in your specific workplace. Additionally, remember that everyone's health comes first – take time off when necessary and seek medical attention if needed.
results.answer: If you become ill during your annual leave, it is important to reach out to your employer as soon as possible to inform them of our situation. If your employment contract includes sick pay benefits or you have access to state sick pay through social welfare, they will need to know how long your illness may last. However, each case depends on individual circumstances, so it would be best to consult with your HR department for accurate advice regarding sickness policies in your specific workplace. Additionally, remember that everyone's health comes first – take time off when necessary and seek medical attention if needed.

results.ground_truth: Generally, your landlord can only end a tenancy after the first 6 months if: You do not comply with the obligations of the tenancy, for example, by not paying your rent on time The property is no longer suited to your needs, for example, if it is too small The landlord intends to sell the property within 9 months. However, this may not apply if the landlord plans to sell 10 or more dwellings in a development within a 6-month period – see ‘Restriction on terminating when selling multiple properties’ below The landlord needs the property for their own use or for an immediate family member (this only applies to private landlords) The landlord plans to change the use of the property (for example, convert it from residential use to office use) The landlord intends to refurbish the property substantially
results.question: What is a valid reason for ending a tenancy after the first 6 months?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is a valid reason for ending a tenancy after the first 6 months?

Helpful Answer:

Under Irish law, either you or your landlord can end an Assured Shorthold Tenancy (AST) by giving notice at any time as long as it has been in place for more than six months. However, there must be a valid reason for terminating the tenancy. Some common reasons include:
1. Your landlord needs the property back to live in it themselves or a family member (known as repossession).
2. The rented premises need significant repairs or alterations that require vacant possession.
3. Both you and the owner agree in writing to bring the tenancy to an early end.
4. In certain cases, such as persistent non-payment of rent or breaches of
results.answer:
Under Irish law, either you or your landlord can end an Assured Shorthold Tenancy (AST) by giving notice at any time as long as it has been in place for more than six months. However, there must be a valid reason for terminating the tenancy. Some common reasons include:
- Your landlord needs the property back to live in it themselves or a family member (known as repossession).
- The rented premises need significant repairs or alterations that require vacant possession.
- Both you and the owner agree in writing to bring the tenancy to an early end.

results.ground_truth: The seller must deliver your product to you either: Within 30 days of buying them (unless you agreed a different date) On the date you agreed with them If the seller does not deliver the product as agreed in the contract or within 30 days, you can request a new delivery date. You can insist that all items you bought in the one transaction are delivered at once. The seller cannot make you accept deliveries in instalments. You can end the contract if: The seller cannot or refuses to deliver within the new time frame you request A new delivery date is no longer suitable for you, for example, you needed the product for a specific date or event You must tell the business you are using your right to end your contract for non-delivery. The business must give you a refund within 14 days. The European Consumer Centre (ECC) Ireland has a letter template which may be helpful.
results.question: What are your rights when an order is delayed or not delivered?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What are your rights when an order is delayed or not delivered?

Helpful Answer:

If you have purchased goods online from within the European Union (EU) but they do not arrive as agreed, or if they don't match the description provided, you may be entitled to certain legal protections under EU consumer legislation known as 'Distance Selling'. This applies even if there was no explicit mention of these protections in the terms and conditions that came with your purchase. Here are some key points about your rights in case of delayed or undelivered orders:

1. **Right to Cancellation**: In most cases, you can withdraw from the contract without giving any reason within 14 days after receiving the item(s). If you exercise this right after having received the goods, then you will generally
results.answer:
If you have purchased goods online from within the European Union (EU) but they do not arrive as agreed, or if they don't match the description provided, you may be entitled to certain legal protections under EU consumer legislation known as 'Distance Selling'. This applies even if there was no explicit mention of these protections in the terms and conditions that came with your purchase. Here are some key points about your rights in case of delayed or undelivered orders:

- **Right to Cancellation**: In most cases, you can withdraw from the contract without giving any reason within 14 days after receiving the item(s).

results.ground_truth: To adopt a child, you must be at least 21 years of age and resident in Ireland. If you are adopting the child as a couple, and one of you is the child’s mother or father or relative, only one of you must be at least 21. There is no upper age limit for adoptive parents. You can adopt if you are: A married couple living together A couple living together in a civil partnership A couple cohabiting together (living together and in a committed relationship) for at least 3 years The mother, father or relative of the child (relative meaning a grandparent, brother, sister, uncle or aunt of the child, and/or the spouse of any such person; the relationship to the child being traced through the mother or the father) If you are a sole applicant (applying for adoption on your own), and you do not fall into any of the categories listed above, you may only adopt if the Adoption Authority of Ireland is satisfied with the particular circumstances of the case.
results.question: Who can adopt a child in Ireland?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: Who can adopt a child in Ireland?

Helpful Answer:
In Ireland, both married couples or individuals over 25 years old (either single or cohabiting) can apply individually or jointly to become foster carers or adopters. However, there are certain eligibility criteria that must be met, such as having a stable home environment, undergoing an assessment by TUSLA - Child and Family Agency, providing medical reports, Garda vetting checks, as well as complying with legal requirements related to adoption orders and parental consent. For comprehensive guidance, visit https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/family/children_in_the_law/adoption.html
results.answer: In Ireland, both married couples or individuals over 25 years old (either single or cohabiting) can apply individually or jointly to become foster carers or adopters. However, there are certain eligibility criteria that must be met, such as having a stable home environment, undergoing an assessment by TUSLA - Child and Family Agency, providing medical reports, Garda vetting checks, as well as complying with legal requirements related to adoption orders and parental consent. For comprehensive guidance, visit https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/family/children_in_the_law/adoption.

results.ground_truth: Penalty points are recorded on your driving licence when: You are convicted in court of a driving offence that attracts penalty points or You pay a fixed charge notice that was issued to you for an offence that also carries penalty points If you get 12 penalty points in any 3 year period, you are automatically disqualified from driving for 6 months. Learner permit drivers are disqualified if they have 7 penalty points. This lower threshold also applies for the first 2 years of a driver’s first full driving licence. Penalty points are not added to your licence immediately. Fixed charge and penalty offences Fixed notice penalties are issued for driving offences that attract penalty points and/or just a fine. If you receive a fixed notice penalty, you will be issued a notice by the Department of Transport. If you pay the fixed charge fine within 56 days, you will get a further notice from the Department of Transport confirming that the penalty points will be added to your driving licence. The penalty points will be added to your licence 28 days after that. If you do not pay the fixed charge fine within 56 days, you will get a summons to appear in the District Court. If you are convicted of a driving offence in court, the court will notify the Department of Transport of the number of penalty points attached to that conviction. The Department of Transport will then issue a notification that these penalty points will be added to your driving licence 28 days after the notification date. You can get information on fixed charge notices and fines in our document on driving offences.
results.question: How do penalty points work?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: How do penalty points work?

Helpful Answer:
Penalty points are used in Ireland as a system for deterring and punishing road traffic offences. If you commit an offence, such as speeding or not wearing a seat belt, you may receive between 2 and 10 points on your driver licence. The specific number of points depends on the severity of the offence. When accumulating more than 12 points within three years (also known as "the period"), you will face a ban from driving. The length of this suspension can vary depending on the total number of points received during that period. It's essential to be aware that if you have fewer than six penalty point convictions, they remain active for a fixed period. This means you
results.answer: Penalty points are used in Ireland as a system for deterring and punishing road traffic offences. If you commit an offence, such as speeding or not wearing a seat belt, you may receive between 2 and 10 points on your driver licence. The specific number of points depends on the severity of the offence. When accumulating more than 12 points within three years (also known as "the period"), you will face a ban from driving. The length of this suspension can vary depending on the total number of points received during that period. It's essential to be aware that if you have fewer than six penalty point convictions, they remain active for a fixed period.

results.ground_truth: To be eligible for a statutory redundancy payment, you must: Be over 16 Be in employment that is fully insurable under the Social Welfare Acts Have at least 2 years’ continuous employment (104 weeks) with the same employer over the age of 16 Have been made redundant (dismissed from your job). You must have been dismissed from your job To show you were dismissed, your employment must have been terminated (with or without notice). There will also be a dismissal if you have ended your contract of employment because you were forced to leave your job because of your employer’s conduct. This is known as constructive dismissal.
results.question: Do I have a right to redundancy pay?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: Do I have a right to redundancy pay?

Helpful Answer:
Your entitlement to redundancy pay depends on several factors such as if you meet certain employment conditions and age limits. Generally, an employee must be over 16 years old and have at least one year of continuous service with their employer. For more specific details or to check whether you qualify, it is recommended to contact the Workplace Relations Commission directly through their LoCall number 1890 808 002 (Monday – Friday from 9am to 5pm). Their staff can provide guidance and answer any questions regarding your situation. You may also find useful guidance by visiting the Irish Government's CITIZENS INFORMATION website - www.citizensinformation.ie

Their staff can provide guidance and answer any questions regarding your situation. results.ground_truth: You must complete the application form and provide supporting documents. You can apply for most payments online. You can also get an application form from your local Intreo Centre or Social Welfare Branch Office or your local Citizens Information Centre. You can also get an application form on gov.ie. Your Intreo Centre, Social Welfare Branch Office or your local Citizens Information Centre can help you fill in your application form. Birth certs for social welfare You are no longer required to provide copies of birth certificates for social welfare purposes if you were born in Ireland and your birth is in the Register of Births. The Department of Social Protection can access this information directly. You can get more information about getting a Birth, Marriage or Death certificate.

Question: How to apply for social welfare?

Helpful Answer:

To apply for Social Welfare in Ireland, you will need to follow these steps:

1. Gather essential documents - prepare original valid photo ID (such as passport or driving license) and proof of PPS number if available. If you don’t have one yet, you can apply at any government office from Monday to Friday 9 am – 4 pm. Additionally, be ready with your bank account details or building society book if you want to receive payments directly into that account.
2. Decide what support you require - different types of assistance include Jobseeker's Benefit/ Allowance, Disability Allowance, One-Parent Family Payment, Carers Allowance, etc. Visit www.w

results.ground_truth: You must make comments about planning applications in writing to the local authority where the application was made. You may be able to do this on your local authority's website. If possible, you should quote the planning application's reference number. You must also give your: Name Address Phone number Email address (if you have one)
results.question: How can I comment on a planning application?

Question: How can I comment on a planning application?

Helpful Answer:

To make comments or objections regarding a planning application in Ireland, follow these steps:
1. Visit the local authority (county/ city council) website where the development is located. Look for the Planning section, usually under Services or Development.
2. Find the Planning Application Register and search using the Reference number if you have it, or the applicant's name and address.
3. Once you find the planning application, there should be an option to "Make submission online" or similar wording. Click on that button.
4. It will typically require you to provide some personal details like name, address, phone number, etc., then ask for your comments or objections related to the proposed development. Make sure
results.answer:
To make comments or objections regarding a planning application in Ireland, follow these steps:
- Visit the local authority (county/ city council) website where the development is located. Look for the Planning section, usually under Services or Development.
- Find the Planning Application Register and search using the Reference number if you have it, or the applicant's name and address.
- Once you find the planning application, there should be an option to "Make submission online" or similar wording. Click on that button.
- It will typically require you to provide some personal details like name, address, phone number, etc., then ask for your comments or objections related to the proposed development.

results.ground_truth: Citizens Information Services (CISs) provide face-to-face services to the public. Through trained staff and volunteers, CISs provide free, impartial and confidential information, advice and advocacy services to the public. Each Citizens Information Service covers a geographical area and delivers the service through a network of Citizen Information Centres (CICs). There are eight individual regional Citizens Information Services which are companies limited by guarantee and are registered charities. They cover the following areas: North Dublin, Dublin South, North Connacht and Ulster, North Leinster, North Munster, South Connacht, South Leinster and South Munster facilitating both rural and urban areas. CISs provide information on various topics, including; Employment rights Income support Social welfare Family matters Health services Housing Education Immigration
results.question: What is the Citizens Information Service?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is the Citizens Information Service?

Helpful Answer:
The Citizens Information Service (CIS) provides free, confidential, correct, and easy-to-understand information on rights and entitlements through an online database, a nationwide network of libraries, and a telephone helpline - 0761 07 4080 (Monday to Friday from 9 am to 5 pm). Additionally, they offer multilingual services with resources in several languages other than English. The purpose of CIS is to help people make informed decisions about their lives by ensuring that everyone who needs the support benefits equally, including those facing challenges related to accessing or understanding public services.
results.answer: The Citizens Information Service (CIS) provides free, confidential, correct, and easy-to-understand information on rights and entitlements through an online database, a nationwide network of libraries, and a telephone helpline - 0761 07 4080 (Monday to Friday from 9 am to 5 pm). Additionally, they offer multilingual services with resources in several languages other than English. The purpose of CIS is to help people make informed decisions about their lives by ensuring that everyone who needs the support benefits equally, including those facing challenges related to accessing or understanding public services.

results.ground_truth: People aged between 18 and 24 and: Had been out of work and getting a qualifying payment (see below) for at least 12 months or Faced a significant barrier to work (if unemployed for less than 12 months) What were the qualifying payments? You must have been getting one of the following payments for at least 12 months: Jobseeker's Benefit, Jobseeker's Allowance, Jobseeker's Transitional payment, One-Parent Family Payment, Disability Allowance, Blind Person’s Pension, or Supplementary Welfare Allowance. Other schemes that counted towards the qualifying period The 12-month qualifying period could also have included time spent on schemes such as: SOLAS training apprenticeships, Youthreach, Back to Education Allowance, Fastrack to Information Technology and Tús.
results.question: Who was eligible for YESS (Youth Employment Support Scheme)?
results.raw_answer:

Question: Who was eligible for YESS (Youth Employment Support Scheme)?

Helpful Answer:

The Youth Employment Support Scheme (YESS) was an initiative aimed at providing employment supports to young people aged 18-29 who were not in education, training, or employment. Those previously on Jobseeker's Allowance, Disability Allowance, Farm Assist, One-Parent Family Payment where their child/ children have reached the age of 14, and those with no previous work history could apply if they fulfilled certain criteria such as being available to start work immediately, actively seeking work while participating in the scheme, among others. It is important to note that YESS concluded on March 31, 2022. If you need help finding employment support options currently available in
results.answer: The Youth Employment Support Scheme (YESS) was an initiative aimed at providing employment supports to young people aged 18-29 who were not in education, training, or employment. Those previously on Jobseeker's Allowance, Disability Allowance, Farm Assist, One-Parent Family Payment where their child/ children have reached the age of 14, and those with no previous work history could apply if they fulfilled certain criteria such as being available to start work immediately, actively seeking work while participating in the scheme, among others. It is important to note that YESS concluded on March 31, 2022.

results.ground_truth: If you are a carer you may need to take breaks. Respite care is when you can take a break from caring, and the person you care for is looked after by someone else. It can be covered by family members or an organisation so you can take a short break, a holiday or a rest. Respite care can be for carers of older people or people with different disabilities. Respite care can cover different lengths of time such as: A very short time, for example for an evening Or a much longer arrangement, for example for a holiday Respite care schemes are sometimes called 'Breakaway' or 'Friendship' schemes.
results.question: What is respite care?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is respite care?

Helpful Answer:
Respite care is temporary support provided to help carers have a break from their caring role. This can be arranged for a short period or longer if required. The aim of respite care is to give regular carers an opportunity for rest, relaxation, and other activities that may not otherwise be possible while they are caring for someone else.

In Ireland, there are various types of respite care services available such as home care, in-patient (hospital) care, daycare centers, and outreach services. These options enable dependent individuals to get necessary supervision and social interaction while allowing primary caregivers some time off. It's essential for both the carer and the person being cared for, as it helps maintain quality
results.answer:

The aim of respite care is to give regular carers an opportunity for rest, relaxation, and other activities that may not otherwise be possible while they are caring for someone else.

In Ireland, there are various types of respite care services available such as home care, in-patient (hospital) care, daycare centers, and outreach services. These options enable dependent individuals to get necessary supervision and social interaction while allowing primary caregivers some time off.

results.ground_truth: If you have a medical card, you can get certain health services free of charge. Usually, your dependent spouse or partner and your children can also get the same range of health services for free. Your medical card is issued by the Health Service Executive (HSE).
results.question: What is a medical card?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is a medical card?

Helpful Answer:
A Medical Card is a document issued by the Health Service Executive (HSE) in Ireland that entitles its holder to free public healthcare services provided by doctors, dentists, hospitals, and pharmacists. To be eligible, individuals must meet certain income, means-tested criteria or have specific medical conditions requiring frequent hospitalization. There are also some special categories like children under six years old, certain patients with long-term illnesses, and those over 70 who may qualify for a medical card without meeting the financial requirements. The purpose of this scheme is to ensure everyone has access to necessary healthcare regardless of their economic situation. For more detailed information on qualifications and application process, please visit the HSE website at www.h

There are also some special categories like children under six years old, certain patients with long-term illnesses, and those over 70 who may qualify for a medical card without meeting the financial requirements. The purpose of this scheme is to ensure everyone has access to necessary healthcare regardless of their economic situation. results.ground_truth: Pre-nuptial agreements have no basis in law in Ireland. As a result, they are not strictly binding. This means that if you have a pre-nuptial agreement in place and you end up in court following the breakdown of your marriage, the judge is not bound by the terms of the pre-nuptial agreement. The only provision in Irish law is under sections 113 and 113A of the Succession Act 1965 (as amended) where a spouse or a civil partner can renounce his/her legal right share in a pre-nuptial agreement. Although they are not legally binding, there is nothing in Irish law which stops a couple planning to marry from having and signing a pre-nuptial agreement. Importantly, such agreements can serve as guides for the courts in judicial separation and divorce cases. If a pre-nuptial agreement makes ‘proper provision’ for each person it is more likely to be persuasive on the judge. Therefore, in situations where one party is likely to inherit a significant family farm or business, it will guide the judge in the divorce or judicial separation on what the parties’ intentions were at the outset.
results.question: What is the legal status of pre-nuptial agreements?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is the legal status of pre-nuptial agreements?

Helpful Answer:
Pre-nuptial agreements were not previously recognized by law in Ireland, but under the Family Law (Divorce) Act 1996 as amended through the Civil Partnership and Certain Rights and Obligations of Cohabitants Act 2010, courts have been empowered to make financial provision on divorce or separation which may give effect to an agreement entered into before marriage if the court considers it fair with regard to all the circumstances of the case. In practice, this means parties can agree on how their assets will be divided should they separate, though these agreements must still meet certain criteria and pass various tests to ensure fairness when being considered by a judge during a divorce or separation proceeding. The
results.answer: Pre-nuptial agreements were not previously recognized by law in Ireland, but under the Family Law (Divorce) Act 1996 as amended through the Civil Partnership and Certain Rights and Obligations of Cohabitants Act 2010, courts have been empowered to make financial provision on divorce or separation which may give effect to an agreement entered into before marriage if the court considers it fair with regard to all the circumstances of the case. In practice, this means parties can agree on how their assets will be divided should they separate, though these agreements must still meet certain criteria and pass various tests to ensure fairness when being considered by a judge during a divorce or separation proceeding.

results.ground_truth: The Department of Transport regulates air transport. This includes commercial and private services. EU airlines can fly freely within the EU/European Economic Area (EEA). They can do this without any restrictions on flight frequency or routes. Airlines from countries outside of the EU/EEA must request permission. They must do this each time they want to fly to, from, or over Ireland. The Department of Defence regulates military air transport in Ireland.
results.question: Who regulates aviation in Ireland?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: Who regulates aviation in Ireland?

Helpful Answer:
The body responsible for regulating aviation in Ireland is called the Irish Aviation Authority (IAA). It ensures safety on Irish-registered aircraft as well as at airports within the country. The IAA was established by an Act of Parliament in 1946. For more detailed questions about the IAA or other aspects of aviation regulation, you may find additional resources on their website or through contacts provided therein.
results.answer: The body responsible for regulating aviation in Ireland is called the Irish Aviation Authority (IAA). It ensures safety on Irish-registered aircraft as well as at airports within the country. The IAA was established by an Act of Parliament in 1946. For more detailed questions about the IAA or other aspects of aviation regulation, you may find additional resources on their website or through contacts provided therein.

results.ground_truth: Under the Cycle to Work Scheme (also known as the Bike to Work Scheme), you can get a new bike tax free through your work. Your employer pays for a new bike and then you repay the cost of regular instalments from your gross (overall) salary. You do not have to pay tax, PRSI or the Universal Social Charge on your repayments. Not every employer takes part in the scheme. However, if they do, they must offer it to all their employees. If you are self-employed, you cannot take part in the Cycle to Work Scheme unless you pay PRSI as an employee in addition to your self-employed work.
results.question: What is the Cycle to Work Scheme?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is the Cycle to Work Scheme?

Helpful Answer:
The Cycle to Work Scheme is an initiative that encourages employees to purchase bicycles and related equipment as a tax-efficient option for commuting and staying active. Under this scheme, employers provide their staff with bicycles and cycling accessories by leasing them over a specified period, usually 12 or 18 months. This means you can save considerable amounts in income tax and National Insurance contributions while gaining a new bike with all necessary safety gear. Keep in mind that each employee may avail of the scheme up to its annual cap - currently €1,050 per individual. For more detailed information on eligibility criteria and participating retails, visit www.bikeireland.ie/cycletowork
results.answer: The Cycle to Work Scheme is an initiative that encourages employees to purchase bicycles and related equipment as a tax-efficient option for commuting and staying active. Under this scheme, employers provide their staff with bicycles and cycling accessories by leasing them over a specified period, usually 12 or 18 months. This means you can save considerable amounts in income tax and National Insurance contributions while gaining a new bike with all necessary safety gear. Keep in mind that each employee may avail of the scheme up to its annual cap - currently €1,050 per individual. For more detailed information on eligibility criteria and participating retails, visit www.bikeireland.

results.ground_truth: Operating hours vary by stop and direction of service. You can view Luas operating hours and Luas frequency on luas.ie. There are electronic displays telling you the time of the next tram at every Luas stop. In addition, there are electronic displays and announcements informing passengers of the next stop on board every tram. Special services operate during Christmas, New Year and on other occasions.
results.question: What are the operating hours and frequency of the Luas?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What are the operating hours and frequency of the Luas?

Helpful Answer:
The Luas is a light rail system serving Dublin, Ireland's capital city. The Luas operates every day (including weekends). The trams run from early morning until late evening, but exact times vary depending on specific lines and directions. For precise schedules and up-to-date information, you can visit www.luas.ie or consult apps that provide real-time transportation updates like MyWay App. Additionally, timetables are displayed at each Luas stop for passengers' reference.
